articles.title: In Photos: Holi 2015
articles.description: Every year, UCSB Indus hosts the South Asian Festival of Colors, commonly known as Holi. This ancient Hindu religious festival is celebrated all throughout the world. UCSB Indus hosts this festival at...
articles.content:
Every year, UCSB Indus hosts the South Asian Festival of Colors, commonly known as Holi. This ancient Hindu religious festival is celebrated all throughout the world. UCSB Indus hosts this festival at the beach by the Anacapa and Santa Cruz dorms, as thousands of students dance and throw colored powder everywhere. Here are some photos from Daily Nexus photographers who were brave enough to take their camera into the pit.

Photos by: Lorenzo Basilio, Vivian Bui, Paris Cullen, and Will Tran

Paris Cullen/Daily Nexus

Vivian Bui/Daily Nexus

articles.title: In Photos: Deltopia 2015
articles.description: As spring quarter begins, the students of UCSB prepare for Deltopia, a day of non-stop partying and walking back and forth through the streets of Isla Vista. Along with Deltopia comes a range of event...
articles.content:
As spring quarter begins, the students of UCSB prepare for Deltopia, a day of non-stop partying and walking back and forth through the streets of Isla Vista. Along with Deltopia comes a range of events hosted by UCSB organizations. The Excursion Club hosted First Friday in Perfect Park, while AS Program Board brought Purity Ring to the Thunderdome. On Sunday morning, students and community members helped clean as much trash as possible with tools provided by Adopt-a-Block.

The Excursion Club hosted IV First Friday, with live performances by local Isla Vista bands. Alexander Payne/Daily Nexus

Students and residents of Isla Vista roam Del Playa. Lorenzo Basilio/Daily Nexus

A student walking down Sabado Tarde throws glitter on a passerby. Vivian Bui/Daily Nexus

Reaching for the win, gauchos race to place Velcro pads while pulled back by a rope. Eric Swenson/Daily Nexus

Local IV Band “Four Closure” performs outside the Thunderdome. Alexander Payne/Daily Nexus

Police mounted on horses stroll through the streets of Isla Vista. Anna Kodelashvili/Daily Nexus

Water bottles were given out to passersby to keep them hydrated during Deltopia. Will Tran/Daily Nexus

Balconies of houses on Del Playa were filled with party-goers. Vivian Bui/Daily Nexus

Chancellor Yang and Dilling Yang walk through Isla Vista. Lorenzo Basilio/Daily Nexus

Antonio Cuna, a.k.a. Sweater Beats, opened for Purity Ring during the Warm-Up Concert hosted by Program Board. Lorenzo Basilio/Daily Nexus

Purity Ring performed at the Warm-Up Concert in the Thunderdome, hosted by AS Program Board. Lorenzo Basilio/Daily Nexus

The festival did not end without leaving a mess, such as this house on Del Playa. Alex Gonzalez/Daily Nexus

Trash bins were full of empty boxes of food and alcoholic drinks. Alex Gonzalez/Daily Nexus

Houses such as this one on the corner of Camino del Sur and Pasado were left trashed. Sarah Kouklis/Daily Nexus

Students and community members worked together to remove trash from the streets on Sunday Morning, with the help of Adopt-a-Block. Paris Cullen/Daily Nexus

Hundreds of volunteers helped pick up trash off the streets on Sunday Morning. Paris Cullen/Daily Nexus

 

 

Print

articles.title: In Photos: Battle of the Bands 2015
articles.description: On Thursday, Jan. 12, five local bands in the UCSB and Isla Vista area competed in the annual Battle of the Bands. In years past, the winner has earned a spot to perform as the opening act at UCS...
articles.content:
On Thursday, Jan. 12, five local bands in the UCSB and Isla Vista area competed in the annual Battle of the Bands. In years past, the winner has earned a spot to perform as the opening act at UCSB’s own Extravaganza. This year, the winning act gets time to record a three-song demo at Rose Lane Studio in Carpenteria. The bands wowed fans with psychedelic sounds and groovy tunes, as Four Closure was deemed victorious.

Photos by Cameryn Brock, Daily Nexus

articles.title: In Photos: 30th Annual Santa Barbara International Film Festival
articles.description: Every year, some of Hollywood’s biggest actors and directors, as well as rising filmmakers make their way to the Downtown Santa Barbara for two weeks, receiving various awards and watching numer...
articles.content:
Every year, some of Hollywood’s biggest actors and directors, as well as rising filmmakers make their way to the Downtown Santa Barbara for two weeks, receiving various awards and watching numerous new films. The Daily Nexus was able to get up close and personal and interview stars such as Jennifer Aniston, Felicity Jones and Michael Keaton.

Photos by Lorenzo Basilio

Thursday, Jan. 29: Cinema Vanguard Award honoring Eddie Redmayne and Felicity Jones

Felicity Jones of The Theory of Everything. (Lorenzo Basilio/Daily Nexus)

Eddie Redmayne of The Theory of Everything. (Lorenzo Basilio/Daily Nexus)

More coverage about the Cinema Vanguard Award HERE

 

Friday, Jan. 30: Montecito Award honoring Jennifer Aniston

Jennifer Aniston poses on the red carpet for her tribute event. (Lorenzo Basilio/Daily Nexus)

(Lorenzo Basilio/Daily Nexus)

More coverage on the Montecito Award HERE

 

Saturday, Jan. 31: Maltin Modern Master Award honoring Michael Keaton

(Lorenzo Basilio/Daily Nexus)

(Lorenzo Basilio/Daily Nexus)

More coverage on the Maltin Modern Master Award HERE

 

Sunday, Feb. 1: Virtuosos Award honoring Chadwick Boseman, Ellar Coltrane, Logan Lerman, David Oyelowo, Rosamund Pike, J.K. Simmons, and Jenny Slate

Rosamund Pike (Gone Girl) received the Virtuosos award. (Lorenzo Basilio/Daily Nexus)

Ellar Coltrane of Boyhood arrives at the Arlington Theatre. (Lorenzo Basilio/Daily Nexus)

Logan Lerman was one of the seven recipients of the Virtuosos Award. (Lorenzo Basilio/Daily Nexus)

Jenny Slate (Obvious Child), recipient of the Virtuosos Award. (Lorenzo Basilio/Daily Nexus)

David Oyelowo recalls his experience preparing for the role of Martin Luther King. Jr in the film Selma. (Lorenzo Basilio/Daily Nexus)

Chadwick Boseman accepts his Virtuosos Award for his role as James Brown in Get on Up. (Lorenzo Basilio/Daily Nexus)

(Left to right): David Oyelowo, Logan Lerman, Ellar Coltrane, Rosamund Pike, J.K. Simmons, Chadwick Boseman, and Jenny Slate receive their Virtuosos Award. (Lorenzo Basilio/Daily Nexus)

More coverage on the Virtuosos Award, including interviews with all recipients HERE

 

Thursday, Feb. 5: American Riviera Award honoring Patricia Arquette and Ethan Hawke

Ethan Hawke with a smirk as he walks down the red carpet. (Lorenzo Basilio/Daily Nexus)

Patricia Arquette speaks on behalf of her American Riviera Award with co-star Ethan Hawke from Boyhood. (Lorenzo Basilio/Daily Nexus)

Ellar Coltrane (middle) gave a speech honoring his Boyhood co-stars Ethan Hawke and Patricia Arquette for their American Riviera Award. (Lorenzo Basilio/Daily Nexus)

More coverage on the American Riviera Award HERE

 

Friday, Feb. 6: Outstanding Performer of the Year Award honoring Steve Carell

Steve Carell takes selfies with fans. (Lorenzo Basilio/Daily Nexus)

Steve Carell revisits his film career during his tribute event on Feb. 5 (Lorenzo Basilio/Daily Nexus)

Jennifer Garner made a surprise visit as she presents the Outstanding Performer of the Year Award to Steve Carell. (Lorenzo Basilio/Daily Nexus)

Steve Carell wins Outstanding Performer of the Year for his role in Foxcatcher. (Lorenzo Basilio/Daily Nexus)

More coverage on the Outstanding Performer of the Year Award HERE

 

Saturday, Feb. 7: Closing Night screening of McFarland, U.S.A.

The seven boys who portrayed the high-school cross country team in McFarland, USA. (Lorenzo Basilio/Daily Nexus)

The cast of McFarland, USA. (Lorenzo Basilio/Daily Nexus)

Kevin Costner and his wife Christine Baumgartner. (Lorenzo Basilio/Daily Nexus)

More coverage on the closing night and the screening HERE

articles.title: In Photos: UCSB Washed Away by Rain
articles.description: Mother Nature delivered much needed rain on Tuesday. UCSB students tried their best to deal with the downpour.
articles.content:
Mother Nature delivered much needed rain on Tuesday. UCSB students tried their best to deal with the downpour.

Photo credits: Stephen Manga, Cameryn Brock

A student browses on her phone outside of the UCen. Cameryn Brock/Daily Nexus

A student walks back to the Santa Cruz residence hall after class. Stephen Manga/Daily Nexus

A student jogs through the rain outside the San Nicolas residence hall. Stephen Manga/Daily Nexus

The rain puddles on campus were deep, and many students came to class with soaked feet. Stephen Manga/Daily Nexus

A student tries to skateboard through puddles on campus during the downpour on Tuesday. Stephen Manga/Daily Nexus

A student forgot to bring an umbrella with her to class, and got soaked as a result. Stephen Manga/Daily Nexus

Students struggle through the rain outside the De La Guerra dining commons. Stephen Manga/Daily Nexus

Students wait outside the UCen after a fire alarm triggered the evacuation of the entire building shortly after noon. Cameryn Brock/Daily Nexus

A maintenance worker wades through the deep puddles while a firetruck passes by the UCen. Stephen Manga/Daily Nexus

Students call their friends to let them know that the UCen has been evacuated. Stephen Manga/Daily Nexus

Firefighters arrived at the UCen several minutes after the fire alarm was triggered. No fire threats were found. Stephen Manga/Daily Nexus

A groundskeeper removes fallen palm tree branches outside the residence halls near campus. Stephen Manga/Daily Nexus

articles.title: IN PHOTOS: Protests in Santa Barbara
articles.description: Local activists and students protesting the recent Missouri grand jury decision to not indict police officer Darren Wilson in the shooting death of Michael Brown assembled in front of the Santa Barbar...
articles.content:
Local activists and students protesting the recent Missouri grand jury decision to not indict police officer Darren Wilson in the shooting death of Michael Brown assembled in front of the Santa Barbara County Courthouse before marching down the streets of the city.

Photo credits: Christina DeMarzo, Will Tran

A local activist speaks to the crowd in front of the Santa Barbara County Courthouse. Protesters initially congregated in front of the Courthouse before marching onto the streets. Christina DeMarzo/Daily Nexus

Protesters holding candles in memory of Michael Brown listen to a speaker in front of the Santa Barbara County Courthouse. Christina DeMarzo/Daily Nexus

Protesters bearing signs in support for Mike Brown and decrying the Missouri grand jury decision on Monday congregate in front of the Santa Barbara County Courthouse. Christina DeMarzo/Daily Nexus

Protesters march down State Street in Santa Barbara. Christina DeMarzo/Daily Nexus

Protesters march down State Street in downtown Santa Barbara. Christina DeMarzo/Daily Nexus

Protesters and police stand off on the intersection of Carillo and Bath Streets in downtown Santa Barbara. Christina DeMarzo/Daily Nexus

Protesters illuminated by police lights chant in front of a line formed by police officers. Christina DeMarzo/Daily Nexus

A woman walks between police officers and protesters. Christina DeMarzo/Daily Nexus

A Santa Barbara police officer in riot gear is illuminated by police lights. Christina DeMarzo/Daily Nexus

Protesters chant slogans while sitting on the intersection of State and Carillo Streets in Santa Barbara. Christina DeMarzo/Daily Nexus

Protesters chant slogans while sitting on the intersection of State and Carillo Streets in Santa Barbara. Christina DeMarzo/Daily Nexus

Protesters bearing signs in support for Mike Brown march down State Street in Santa Barbara. Christina DeMarzo/Daily Nexus

A candlelight vigil for Mike Brown was held at the A.S. Pardall Center on Tuesday night. Will Tran/Daily Nexus

articles.title: IN PHOTOS: UCSB eliminated from the Big West Semis
articles.description: On Wednesday, the UCSB men’s soccer squad competed against a slumping UC Irvine squad–whom they beat earlier this season–to advance past the Big West semifinals. The Anteaters denied...
articles.content:
On Wednesday, the UCSB men’s soccer squad competed against a slumping UC Irvine squad–whom they beat earlier this season–to advance past the Big West semifinals. The Anteaters denied them passage into the Big West finals, defeating the Gauchos 3-2 to gain a much-needed confidence boost.

The Gauchos now wait to see if they will continue their season into the NCAA tournament. The NCAA Selection Committee will put together the 48-team field next week.

Photos by Eric Swenson, Kenneth Song

Players gather together before the playing of the National Anthem. (Eric Swenson/Daily Nexus)

UCSB players celebrate after Drew Murphy scored in the first 54 seconds of the match. (Eric Swenson/Daily Nexus)

Defender Dylan Murphy (23) tries to kick the ball away from midfielder Gor Kirakosyan during the first half of the match. (Kenneth Song/Daily Nexus)

Anteaters and Gauchos battle for the ball. (Eric Swenson/Daily Nexus)

UC Irvine’s Michael Sperber (32) and UCSB’s Ismaila Jome tumble into the grass during the second half of the match. (Kenneth Song/Daily Nexus)

Nick DePuy (6, far left) kneels on the grass in disbelief after he missed the goal on a 1v1 opportunity. Conversely, UCI defender Matthew Tilley (4) expresses his relief to his teammate Mitchell Alvarez (9). (Kenneth Song/Daily Nexus)

Defender Jack Birkenbeuel (left) and Nick DePuy struggle for the ball during the first half of the match. (Kenneth Song/Daily Nexus)

About 1900 people attended the UCSB-UC Irvine matchup on Wednesday. (Eric Swenson/Daily Nexus)

UCSB and UCI players alike prepare for a UCSB penalty kick during the second half of the match. (Eric Swenson/Daily Nexus)

UC Irvine goalkeeper Michael Breslin catches the ball away from UCSB’s Dugan Zier. Breslin had five saves in the match. (Eric Swenson/Daily Nexus)

A UCSB player struggles to digest defeat at the hands of the Anteaters, who are seen celebrating their triumph in the background. (Kenneth Song/Daily Nexus)

articles.title: In Photos: Halloween festivities in Isla Vista washed away by rain
articles.description: On Friday, any and all anticipation and fears of an Isla Vista Halloween of unprecedented rambunctiousness were washed away by heavy rain. One more day of Halloween weekend to go. Photo Credits: Anna ...
articles.content:
On Friday, any and all anticipation and fears of an Isla Vista Halloween of unprecedented rambunctiousness were washed away by heavy rain.

One more day of Halloween weekend to go.

Photo Credits: Anna Kodelashvili, Will Tran

The torrential downpour of rain caught Halloween revelers with their pants down–in the case of this man, literally. Photo by Anna Kodelashvili

A man carries a hamper full of clothes (foreground) out of a beached sailboat on the shores of Isla Vista. Photo by Will Tran

Big branches of a tree fell near the restaurants of Pita Pit and Naan Stop between Trigo and Seville roads on Embarcadero del Mar. Photo by Anna Kodelashvili

A Bane casually strolls past a police barricade, apparently thirsty for some coke. Photo by Anna Kodelashvili

First aid stations were set up in Isla Vista to treat potential patients. Photo by Will Tran

There were few persons on the streets during the downpour on Friday. Del Playa Drive was so empty that police officers closed up the barricades blocking the street, allowing traffic to flow on the drive. Photo by Will Tran

articles.title: This Week in Photos: Oct. 7 – 12
articles.description: We look back at this past week in photos. Credits: John Clow, Eric Swenson, Kenneth Song, Christine Skari
articles.content:
We look back at this past week in photos.

Credits: John Clow, Eric Swenson, Kenneth Song, Christine Skari

UCSB Professor and recent Nobel Prize winner Shuji Nakamura speaks with the media after a press conference on October 7, 2014. Nakamura, who said he was awaken early that morning to news he had won the Nobel Prize for his invention of efficient blue light-emitting diodes, is the sixth UCSB faculty member to receive the honor since 1998. John Clow/Daily Nexus

Performers of Schoolhouse Rock go airborne during a performance in Campbell Hall on Sunday. The musical play, which is based on the iconic cartoon series, brought audiences down memory lane with classic songs such as “Conjunction Junction”, “Just a Bill”, “Three is a Magic Number”, and “Interplanet Jane”.  Eric Swenson/Daily Nexus

UCSB’s Tobias Galskov hits an approach shot against Cal’s JT Nishimura in at the UCSB Classic on Sunday. Galskov prevailed over Nishimura 6-4, 6-3 to take third place in Flight A singles. The Gauchos will compete at the ITA Regionals this Friday at Malibu. Kenneth Song/Daily Nexus

Participants of UCSB Larping Battle engage in a large-scale melee at Dogshit Park on Sunday. The LARPING (“Live-Action-Role-Playing”) consisted of two “armies” engaging in hand-to-hand combat much like the close-quarter battles of the Medieval Ages. To ensure fair gameplay, rules were enforced, such as no magic or headshots. Christine Skari/Daily Nexus

Lorde sings in a sold-out show at the Santa Barbara Bowl last Thursday. The wildly popular New Zealand singer-songwriter performed every single song from her sole album Pure Heroine, plus a a brand new song from the soundtrack of the Hunger Games: Mockingjay – Part 1.  Kenneth Song/Daily Nexus

Singer and UCSB alum Jack Johnson held a surprise performance with Animal Liberation Orchestra at Storke Plaza on Wednesday. Johnson and the ALO were part of a commemoration the honored Isla Vista shooting victims and promoted a safer, healthier UCSB and Isla Vista. Kenneth Song/Daily Nexus

Word of Jack Johnson’s presence spread like wildfire in the afternoon before his performance, and students flooded Storke Plaza by the thousands at the commemoration. Kenneth Song/Daily Nexus

Print

articles.title: IN PHOTOS: Jack Johnson at the UCSB Memorial Event
articles.description: Yesterday, the Associated Students Program Board hosted “Come Together: Remember, Reconnect, and Unite” at Storke Plaza to promote a safer, healthier UCSB/Isla Vista community in remembrance to th...
articles.content:
Yesterday, the Associated Students Program Board hosted “Come Together: Remember, Reconnect, and Unite” at Storke Plaza to promote a safer, healthier UCSB/Isla Vista community in remembrance to the six students who lost their lives during the May 23rd tragedy.

The 5,000 students attended the event, not the least motivated by swirling rumors that UCSB alumni Jack Johnson and rock musicians Animal Liberation Orchestra were going to give a surprise performance.

The students were not disappointed. Johnson and the orchestra entertained a warm and welcoming crowd for a good hour and a half.

A Daily Nexus article about this concert can be read here:

Photo Credits: Kenneth Song, Robert Johnson

Johnson and the musicians of Animal Liberation Orchestra received a warm welcome by UCSB students. Robert Johnson/Daily Nexus

Kenneth Song/Daily Nexus

Storke Plaza was packed with some five thousand people, as illustrated in this photo. Kenneth Song/Daily Nexus

Kenneth Song/Daily Nexus

Kenneth Song/Daily Nexus

Kenneth Song/Daily Nexus

Kenneth Song/Daily Nexus

Kenneth Song/Daily Nexus

Kenneth Song/Daily Nexus

Kenneth Song/Daily Nexus

Firefighters were present, and were treated with a music performance from a famed musician. Kenneth Song/Daily Nexus

Kenneth Song/Daily Nexus

Kenneth Song/Daily Nexus

Kenneth Song/Daily Nexus

Bicycle space was at a premium on Wednesday afternoon. Kenneth Song/Daily Nexus

Jack Johnson waves goodbye to his admirers. Kenneth Song/Daily Nexus

articles.title: This Week in Photos: Sept. 28 – Oct. 6
articles.description: We look back at the happenings of this past week in photos.
articles.content:
We look back at the happenings of this past week in photos.

Credits: Cameryn Brock, Dustin Harris, Kenneth Song, Alex Gonzalez

EDM producer 3LAU headlined the Welcome Back Concert on October 4, 2014. (Cameryn Brock/Daily Nexus)

Attendees make noise during the Welcome Back Concert, which featured up-and-coming EDM producer 3LAU. (Cameryn Brock/Daily Nexus)

The Meredith Field scoreboard displays the celebration of the UCSB men’s soccer team, as the Gauchos upset No. 3 UC Irvine 1-0 to hand the Anteaters their first loss of the season on Saturday. (Dustin Harris/Daily Nexus)

Flyers, business cards, and candy line the UCSB Recreational Sports table during the on-campus job fair held in the lawn in front of the De La Guerra dining commons during the Week of Welcome. The fair was an opportunity for first-year students to engage with prospective on-campus employers and to explore other organizations. (Kenneth Song/Daily Nexus)

Bob Weiss, middle, and Richard Martinez, right, stand somberly as congresswoman Lois Capps speak about the recent passage of AB 1014 and SB 505, laws introduced after a murder spree in Isla Vista last May, where six UCSB students lost their lives. Weiss and Martinez both lost their daughter, Veronika, and son, Chris, respectively during the tragic events. (Kenneth Song/Daily Nexus)

UCSB defender Dylan Murphy (center) and Drake forward Steven Enna (left) battle for the ball in a non-conference match at Harder Stadium, Saturday, September 28. UCSB won the match 4-1 in a rout. (Dustin Harris/Daily Nexus)

A fire performer gives a captivating show in Isla Vista on Saturday night. (Alex Gonzalez/Daily Nexus)

Tortillas always had a special place in UCSB’s heart. Tortilla management has become more efficient in the past several years; now there is a special place always waiting for liberated tortillas. (Dustin Harris/Daily Nexus)

articles.title: IN PHOTOS: 3LAU Headlines Welcome Back Concert
articles.description: 3LAU (pronounced “Blau”) shook Storke Plaza this weekend with artfully crafted electro-house mashups, while fellow EDM producer Beni Haze blasted Gauchos with dancey beats and heavy bas...
articles.content:
3LAU (pronounced “Blau”) shook Storke Plaza this weekend with artfully crafted electro-house mashups, while fellow EDM producer Beni Haze blasted Gauchos with dancey beats and heavy bass. With hordes of new students pouring in to see Las Vegas-based progressive house DJ 3LAU and Virginia-bred producer Beni Haze, this year’s Welcome Back Concert culminated in a flurry of bright lights, bright colors, gyrating bodies and a ton of bass.

Photos by Cameryn Brock

articles.title: Photos from the Convocation Ceremony
articles.description: Incoming students of UCSB received a warm welcome from their Chancellor, Henry T. Yang, and UC Regent and UCSB alum George Kieffer on Monday. Photo Credits: Kenneth Song
articles.content:
Incoming students of UCSB received a warm welcome from their Chancellor, Henry T. Yang, and UC Regent and UCSB alum George Kieffer on Monday.

Photo Credits: Kenneth Song

UCSB faculty waltz into Convocation on the Faculty Lawn by the lagoon.

The a cappella group Naked Voices sing the National Anthem before Convocation.

Chancellor Henry T. Yang welcomes the incoming freshmen of the Class of 2018.

George Marshall (in the yellow robe) and Ali Guthy (center right) will new occupations within UCSB: Marshall will serve as the new executive vice chancellor, while Guthy begins her stint as President of Associated Students.

Storke Tower looms in the background while students listen to the Convocation speeches.

Two attendees sneak in a conversation.

An airplane drags a Greek life advertisement above the attendees.

Regent and UCSB alum George Kieffer was the highlight of Convocation.

Outgoing executive vice chancellor Michael Young, center, sits idly during George Kieffer’s speech.

articles.title: In Photos: Summer Solstice Celebration
articles.description: Santa Barbara celebrated the first day of summer with a weekend-long festival in downtown complete with music, dancing, arts and crafts, local vendors, and a Carnival-style parade. Photos by Cameryn B...
articles.content:
Santa Barbara celebrated the first day of summer with a weekend-long festival in downtown complete with music, dancing, arts and crafts, local vendors, and a Carnival-style parade.

Photos by Cameryn Brock / Daily Nexus

Print

articles.title: In Photos: Crime Scenes at IV Deli Mart and 6500 Block of Del Playa
articles.description: Nexus photographer John Clow captured images from two of the biggest crime scenes of the mass shooting spree in Isla Vista: at IV Deli Mart on Pardall Rd, and on the 6500 block of Del Playa drive, whe...
articles.content:
Nexus photographer John Clow captured images from two of the biggest crime scenes of the mass shooting spree in Isla Vista: at IV Deli Mart on Pardall Rd, and on the 6500 block of Del Playa drive, where the shooting suspect Elliot Rodger shot himself to death to end the chase.

All photos by John Clow/Daily Nexus.
